@dotsamamaxi @Rodrigo03078986 Ok so pre-loading in chunks (because the data file is too large to pre-load entirely) actually works! Thank you. It saves ~10% runtime (15min). I guess line by line reading from ssd at 4GB/s was holding up the much faster (~50GB/s) ram task of mutating tge dictionary.
@Leroy75693772 Mtgox hack was in 2011, fund freezing and seizing by US govt in 2013, website down and default in 2014.
@AdAstraBitcoin Weird, this was not faster..

@season_alt Pandas/numpy requires lines of the same length, but the lines in my file are very very different from each other, sometimes with just a couple data items and sometimes with thousands of items.

@SakalleyDhruv couple of reasons:
- the lines must be read/processed in order
- dict inserts must be done before pops/deletes
- doing all inserts and then all pops/deletes results in a too large dictionary in ram (>1TB instead of "just" 56GB when popping/deleting each line)

@satyajugran Currently it processes a 300GB data.txt file and ~4 billion dict mutations in 155 minutes using 56GB ram (mainly for the dictionary). I only want that 155 minutes down and have 128GB ram available.

@chifliiiii @OpenAI Unfortunately "if in d: del" is slower than "d.pop"

And the comprehension only ads to d and does not pop/delete, which means d gets to large in ram (~1540GB instead of "just" 56GB)

@TonyDAugustine That would be great indeed! However inserting and deleting from the dictionary MUST be done in the order of the lines in the data file. I have tried multiprocessing.Pool etc but did not succeed.

@CryptoF51217929 @rampagingruss My point exactly. 2013 deviation was larger than current deviation, was the model invalidated in 2013? I don't think so.

@conjurerofthin1 @rampagingruss Sd is not a level that if crossed invalidates a model. It means, 68% of data must be in 1sd band, 95% in 2sd, 99% in 3sd. S2F model 1sd is ~30k-120k, 2sd ~20k-180k, 3sd ~15k-240k. However model error must also be normally distributed and no autocorrelation, which is not the case.

@jBuzMSC @rampagingruss IMO: cointegration tests show cointegration. However the tests need 2 random/nondeterministic variables. S2f ratio is not entirely random. So we can not use current cointegration tests. Without cointegration the relation between s2f ratio and btc price could be spurious.

Realized price is sort of average cost price. Think of it like moving averages, but instead of equally weighting months, months are weighted by how many BTC moved on-chain that month. S2F model: BTC=a*(S2F ratio)^b
Time model: BTC=a*(months from Jan09)^b

Why I prefer S2F model:
- tells you when price increases: after halvings
- more robust parameters (a,b)
- time not an input variable, S2FX not a time series
- interpolation possible

So S2F model predicts demand

- interpolation (w gold & real estate) vs extrapolation (of time)

@TorbjrnBullJens @PrestonPysh @nntaleb The foundations are actually quite similar. Every investors demands more return for a more risky investment. Same with scarcity. Every investor would rather have a scarce asset than an abundant asset for the same price. It really is quite intuitive.

@TorbjrnBullJens Yes there are practical issues like what is the risk free rate and the assumption of no restrictions (tax, shorting, leverage etc), but most of those are tackled in later iterations of CAPM. And the relationship between risk and return is undebated: there is no free lunch.
@_schmiegle Hmm that is however not correct because 30Y T-bonds have (a lot of) duration risk. I would say 1M T-bills come close to risk free rate. But then again, in Europe they are all negative...

@VKMacro_Mania Not true at all. Investors demand more return for more risky investments. If you had to chose between 10%  guaranteed return and 10% return with chance of losing 50%, you would pick the former. Now how much extra return would you ask for -50% risk? Enter CAPM (or similar models).

@KryptoJoseph @Stroukal @Nicknack1603 Think of it like this: for bitcoin's scarcity it doesn't matter if a bitcoin is with you, me or an exchange. The only thing that matter is how much btc there are and how much new will be made

@AdelEibesh @woonomic Think of it like this: for bitcoin's scarcity it doesn't matter if a bitcoin is with you, me or an exchange. The only thing that matter is how much btc there are and how much new will be made

@Cipherhoodlum @AdelEibesh @woonomic yes, exchanges just get some of your fiat or bitcoin as fees, not new bitcoin. Bitcoin doesn't get more or less scarce because of exchange fees. Only miners create new bitcoin. S2F measure scarcity: existing bitoins (stock) divided by yearly new production (flow).

@SeanLSquire Pair trading  is not so much about correlated assets (moving up and down together) but about cointegrated assets (staying together, their distance is stationary). And indeed normally it is two (randomly moving) assets, in this case one of them is not an asset (S2F) and not random

Cointegration is used by hedge funds in pairs trading (statistical arbitrage). Since #bitcoin stock-to-flow and price are cointegrated, and S2F is predetermined, pairs trading is IMO an interesting asymmetrical return opportunity: btc can go to zero, or 10x. @iam__vance @realvision @RaoulGMI SF model is not for boom/bust cycles, the boom/bust cycles create error in the model (i.e. is not modeled). Sample size is not 3 but 111. Cointegration is what makes me confident.

@BitcoinTina @realvision @RaoulGMI Yes, it is a bit arbitrary. I didn't calculate / predict exactly when the model would fail. But when the cointegration brakes (the line between the dog and the drunk breaks), the model is done.

@waltoshi @realvision @RaoulGMI Like I said before: $55k is the original model (March 22), it's conservative because I thought it was high and didn't want to be too optimistic. @tomasrollo Raspberry 3 doesn't sync the blockchain on its own (Rasp4 does), so you have to copy the folders "blocks" and "chainstate" from another node (260GB). From there the node writes about 1MB blcoks every 10 minutes. You can set swappiness to zero in ubuntu, to reduce OS writes.

@ghostInfLoop advantage is that rasp4 can sync the blockchain on its own.
disadvantage: it probably needs a fan for cooling the cpu

- format SDcard FAT

- extract .xz to SD
- boot Raspi
- sudo apt-add-repository ppa:bitcoin/bitcoin
- sudo apt-get update
- sudo apt-get install bitcoind
- bitcoind -printtoconsole
- copy folder "blocks" + "chainstate" from other node to SD

@johnnyutahbtc SF=stock 17.7 / flow 0.7 = 25
I correct for 1m lost coins: SF=16.7/0.7 = 24
Correcting for 4m lost coins would give SF=13.7/0.7=20
But keep in mind that the formula 0.4*SF^3 was calibrated on 1m lost coins. Other numbers would result in other parameters (not other predictions!)

@IIIIIlllll13 @bitcoinpasada Yes, even 4m, but I can accurately identify the first 1mln (Satoshi's coins), but not the other 3 mln (esp. the timing). BTW it does not matter very much if you correct for lost coins or not, it just changes the parameters of the formula: 0.4*SF^3

ICYDK: #bitcoin stock to flow model / indicator is available in TradingView. Big thanks to yomofoV for implementing it. Data is slightly off because it doesn't correct for 1 mln lost coins (the 0.4*SF^3 formula does!), but you can easily adjust in line 28.

@_drgo One correction: fees do not add to flow. Fees are already existing coins that are payed to a miner, not new coins. Block reward = fees + subsidy (new coins). Only the subsidy / new coins add to flow. So fees are not relevant from a stock-to-flow POV.

@timos_m @JackMallers OK got it. The formula is: geometric mean = arithmetic mean - volatility/2. So, I use GM/AM as a volatility proxy. In other words: if the difference between AM and GM is big, then volatility is large (fat tails / log or power distribution), et vice versa.

Note that by this definition, platinum, palladium and altcoins like ethereum, ripple, litecoin and bcash are not scarce, i.e. they have no value as monetary good. They can have value for other purposes. E.g. palladium and platinum are used in catalytic converters in cars.

Monetary goods like gold, silver, #bitcoin have value because they are scarce: supply/stock (e.g. btc stock 17.5m) cannot be easily forged and is not really impacted by a relatively low production/flow (e.g. btc flow 0.7m/yr). Thus stock-to-flow is high (e.g. btc SF=17.5/0.7=25). https://t.co/uuZ1T11mCR
